Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a renewal proposal for the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute (MSRI), which organizes and hosts a variety of working groups of mathematicians and mathematical scientists, who participate in research and training activities on topics drawn from a broad spectrum of active areas in fundamental mathematics. At any given time during the academic year, MSRI is home to 80-90 leading research professors, members, postdoctoral fellows (as well as around 15 graduate students) from around the country and the world who are organized into semester-long programs (usually two, though, occasionally, one) concentrating in a particular research area. Each program features introductory and research workshops, seminars and lectures, postdoctoral mentoring, and general collaboration between members, with the goal of assimilating and expounding the latest results in the area, stimulating new research and collaborations, and disseminating the results, through traditional publication channels as well as video streaming of lectures. The programs for the next three years include random matrix theory (2010), arithmetic statistics (2011), and quantitative geometry (2012). In addition to the semester-long research programs, MSRI organizes and hosts many workshops each year that benefit the mathematics community; subjects include mathematics education, recent breakthroughs in mathematics, graduate and undergraduate training and research, and mathematical biology. As a result of these combined activities, about 2000 mathematical scientists each year visit MSRI. Meanwhile, the training of a diverse US workforce in the mathematical sciences is a high priority, and MSRI works to increase participation in its activities of women and other under-represented groups.

The Mathematical Sciences Research Institute (MSRI) in Berkeley, CA is one of seven Mathematical Sciences Institutes (http://mathinstitutes.org/) supported by the NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences. The fundamental mission of MSRI is, first and foremost, to support first-rate mathematical research and to develop the human resources needed to sustain and apply the resulting knowledge base and, secondarily, to educate the public about mathematics, its impact and connections. The MSRI supports programs that promote fundamental research in the mathematical sciences by bringing together visiting groups of mathematical scientists from around the US and the world. It hosts semester- and year-long research programs as well as 1- to 2-week workshops, and it conducts mentoring and training of early-career mathematicians. The programs are organized around subjects proposed by members of the mathematics research community that are then developed with the advice and guidance of MSRI's Scientific Advisory Committee, which is comprised of leaders in the mathematical sciences. These programs come from a wide range of areas in mathematics, from number theory (such as the 2011 Arithmetic Statistics Program) to subjects connected to physics and computation (such as the 2012 Quantitative Geometry Program). The MSRI website (http://www.msri.org) describes upcoming and past programs, solicits ideas for future programs, offers application forms for Institute activities, and details MSRI's extensive outreach and education activities, which help expose to the public the inherent beauty and utility of mathematics in modern society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work supported by this grant included major efforts for

 

1) The creation of new mathematical knowledge

2) The development of human scientific capital, with an emphasis on increasing the diversity of the workforce

3) Improve K-12 math education

4) Improve the dissemination of the discussions and results obtained

 

Because the body of this report contains a comprehensive account, we only give examples of the activities.

 

1)     Creation of new mathematical knowledge: MSRI typically convenes two related Programs, or one “Jumbo” Program, each semester. The Programs are configured around rapidly developing topics of scientific importance by MSRI’s Scientific Advisory Committee, a group of highly distinguished mathematical scientists who serve four-year non-renewable terms; in this way, the view of mathematics that is represented is kept constantly fresh. For the duration of a Program, MSRI arguably becomes the world center of research in the field the program represents. Some of the programs, such as the 2010 program on Inverse Problems or the 2013 Program on Optimal Transport have strong connections with applications; in others, such as the 2012 Program on Noncommutative Algebraic Geometry and Representation Theory or the 2014 program on Dynamics on Moduli Spaces of Geometric Structures, the subjects have not yet been applied.

 

The Programs emphasize long stays by senior researchers, often decorated with Fields Medals and other prizes. Another feature is the mix of participants—new postdocs and even some graduate students mingle freely with leaders of the field.

 

To allow more mathematicians to share the benefits of the research in a Program, each one has two large workshops during the semester.  To take account of important developments as they happen, the Scientific Advisory Committee also chooses Hot Topics Workshops.

 

2)     Development of Human Scientific Capital: Each Program recruits 6-10 Postdoctoral Fellows (Postdocs). They stay for the duration of their program—five months. MSRI provides active mentoring, following a carefully developed strategy of assigned senior mentors and careful monitoring by the MSRI Directorate.

 

Despite the tightly defined fields of the program, MSRI has about 10 times as many applicants for the Postdoc positions as there are places. Moreover, nearly every Postdoc who is offered a position accepts it, such is the value placed on coming to MSRI. For many it is indeed a career-defining experience.

 

In the summers, MSRI’s auditorium is filled with students in the Summer Graduate Schools (SGS)—four two-week programs at MSRI, typically with 40-50 students each. These programs are designed to get students from all over working together in groups; they often make friends who will become their colleagues and collaborators for life.

 

MSRI works to strengthen the diversity of U.S. researchers, addressing the issues of under-represented minorities and the under-representation of women. MSRI was the first of the NSF Math Institutes to have a Human Resources Advisory Committee to help organizers recruit minorities and women. MSRI holds the Math Institutes Diversity Grant, a supplement to the Core Grant, through which many special activities to encourage minorities are funded.

 

One of the most effective things that MSRI does to encourage minorities is the Research Experience for Undergraduates, called MSRI-UP. This 6-week summer program carefully chooses 18 students from non-traditional backgrounds, and gives them an intense experience of collaborative research. Many published papers have come out of it! Each student is mentored after the program into the beginning of graduate school. Its success can be seen from the fact that, in 2017, over 60 of its graduates were enrolled in mathematics PhD programs.

 

3)     Improve K-12 Math Education: MSRI organizes an annual workshop on Critical Issues in Math Education, designed to bring research mathematicians, math education professionals, and teachers together in productive collaboration, and to compare the views of these groups in a useful way. For example, the 2014 topic was The Role of the Mathematics Department in the Preparation of Teachers.

 

MSRI was a pioneer in developing math circles in the U.S. These are after-school activities that emphasize open-ended problems and independent investigation, and allow kids to become passionate about mathematics. Part of a supplementary grant for Math Circle Mentorship and Partnership in this period went to activity configured by MSRI’s National Association of Math Circles, as did grants for an annual workshop called Circle on the Road—a gathering where those engaged in running Math Circles can meet to share experiences and best practice.

 

 Dissemination: MSRI publishes video and notes from nearly every workshop lecture. To enhance the usefulness of this resource, and that of the similar but smaller collections at the other NSF Math Institutes, the Math Institutes initiated a project to provide indexing and keywords in a consistent interface across all their collections, and to make this index available to all at the NSF Math Institutes website at https://mathinstitutes.org/videos/.
